info.meta: Administering SUSE Linux Enterprise Server Using Cockpit
How to manage SLES using the Cockpit Web interface

listitem.para: From basic system overview, over storage management to keeping your system up to date, Cockpit enables you to perform a number of administration tasks in a convenient way.
This article is intended to provide a complete overview of tasks that can be performed from the Cockpit Web interface.
The average reading time of this article is approximately 40 minutes.
You will be able to administer your system using Cockpit.
To fully administer the system using Cockpit, you must have sudo privileges.

section.para: Cockpit is a Web-based graphical interface that enables you to manage most administration tasks from one place. You do not need to create credentials for Cockpit as, by default, Cockpit uses the same credentials that you use to log in to your server. Cockpit uses APIs that already exist on the system without adding a layer to the system.
Cockpit enables you to perform the following tasks:

listitem.para: download container images and run containers
manage the server storage
inspect and change network settings
manage user accounts
view system logs
inspect and interact with systemd services
switch between SELinux modes
use a terminal on a remote server in your Web browser

section.title: Cockpit plug-ins
section.para: Cockpit uses plug-ins to administer the system. The plug-ins are included in the installation pattern. However, depending on the technologies installed on your system, some plug-ins may not be visible to you. For example, if NFS is not present, the corresponding NFS panel is not visible.

Cockpit enables you to log in directly to each machine that can expose the 9090 port. This machine is sometimes referred to as the primary server. It is the primary server that runs the cockpit-ws through which connections to additional servers are established. By default, Cockpit listens for both HTTP and HTTPS connections. However, most of the HTTP connections are redirected to HTTPS, with exceptions like local host access.

If the port cannot be accessed on the particular machine, you can still use Cockpit to administer the machine by using it as a secondary server. For a procedure of adding a server as secondary, refer to .

note.title: A limited number of secondary servers
note.para: The number of secondary servers that you can administer from one primary server is limited to 20. If you need to administer more servers, add other primary servers or use another tool for cluster administration.

section.title: TLS certificates
section.para: By default, Cockpit loads .cert or .crt certificates from the directory /etc/cockpit/ws-certs.d. The corresponding private key must be a separate file with the same file name but with the .key suffix. Make sure the key is not encrypted.
If no certificate is found in the directory, Cockpit generates a self-signed certificate (0-self-signed.cert) to establish a secure connection.
To check which certificate Cockpit uses, run the command:

You do not need separate credentials to log in to Cockpit. Use the same credentials that you use to log in to SUSE Linux Enterprise Server. However, on new installations, login using root is not allowed by default. Either enable root login with a password as described in , or create an unprivileged user to access Cockpit. On instances upgraded from a previous release, root login is still allowed. In all cases, we recommend enhancing the security by adding 2FA as described in .
Non-privileged users log in to Cockpit with limited access. To perform administrative tasks, click Limited access in the upper-right menu and unlock the administrative mode by entering root password.

abstract.para: To set up 2FA on SUSE Linux Enterprise Server, you need an available TOTP application of your choice. Then run a command to configure the authorization. The following sections provide details on how to proceed with the configuration of 2FA and also give instructions in situations when your 2FA fails.

section.title: Applications providing TOTP 2FA
section.para: The following applications providing 2FA are supported on SUSE Linux Enterprise Server.

listitem.para: PSONO - available for Firefox, Chrome, Docker, iOS, Android
Google Authenticator - available on Android, iOS and Wear OS
Okta Verify - available on Android, iOS, macOS and Windows
Yubico Authenticator - with a hardware key
KeePassXC - available on Linux desktops, Windows and macOS
KeePassDX - available on Android
FreeOTP Plus - for Android
FreeOTP - for iOS

section.title: Setting up 2FA
section.para: Each user can configure their own 2FA, or root can configure it for any regular user on the system. To set up 2FA for a user from a running system, proceed as follows.

step.para: Run the command:
Scan the code to any TOTP application mentioned above.
Confirm the process by entering an OTP code.

section.title: Recovering access
section.para: Setting up 2FA is optional. However, once set, the second factor is mandatory to log in to Cockpit. If the second factor becomes unavailable, you can change it or disable it. Even without the second factor, you can still log in to the machine using SSH or directly from a console. After login, you can use the following two options:

listitem.para: Run the command either as root or with your user name using sudo:
Remove the file .pam_oath_usersfile from the affected user home directory.

info.title: Enabling root to log in using password

warning.title: root login with password is not secure
warning.para: We strongly discourage you from enabling root login with password for security reasons.

section.para: In new SLES installations, root login using password is disabled by default due to security reasons. To allow root login with password, proceed as follows:

step.para: Open the /etc/cockpit/disallowed-users file.
Remove root from the file.

info.title: Logging in to the primary server directly

section.para: Whenever you have a direct network access to the 9090 port, you can directly log in to the server using your credentials. To do so, follow the .

note.title: No dedicated credentials for Cockpit needed
note.para: By default, the access is controlled by a Cockpit-specific PAM stack located at /usr/lib/pam.d/cockpit. The default configuration allows logging in with the same user names and passwords that are used for any local account on the system.

procedure.title: Logging in to the primary server

step.para: Go to the Cockpit login page by opening the following address in a browser:
Enter the credentials.

section.para: If your machine does not have direct access to the 9090 port, you can use this machine as a secondary server. Ensure that Cockpit is installed on the machine.
There are two ways of logging in to a secondary server: you can log in to a secondary server directly or you can use the primary server.

section.title: Logging in to secondary servers directly
section.para: You can log in to any secondary server without logging in to the primary server first. This solution can be useful when you do not have credentials for the primary server. The primary server will be used as a bridge, and you will be connected to the secondary server using SSH.
To connect to the secondary server, proceed as follows:

step.para: Go to the Cockpit login page by opening the following address in a browser:
Fill in the credentials for the secondary server.
Expand Other options on the login screen.
Fill in the IP address of the secondary server.
Proceed by clicking Login.
If you are trying to log in for the first time, you are asked to verify the fingerprint. After this, click Accept and connect.

section.title: Accessing secondary servers from the primary server
section.para: If you have credentials for the primary server, you can access secondary servers from the primary one. You must add the secondary servers first, as described in .

step.para: Log in to the primary server using the account with the system administrator role.
Click the USERNAME@HOSTNAME in the upper-left corner.
Click Add new host.
Fill in the host identification and optionally user name that will be used to log in to the server. You can assign a color to the machine. When the details are complete, click Add.
Verify a fingerprint on the server you want to add. If the fingerprint matches or if you have not set up the SSH connection, click Trust and add host to proceed.
Fill in the password and, if needed, check Automatic login. Cockpit will generate a new SSH key for the user, and next time you will be logged in automatically.

section.para: By default, a regular user can log in to Cockpit with limited access that does not enable the user to perform administration tasks like managing user accounts, updating the system, and so on.
To switch to administrative access, proceed as follows:

step.para: Click the Limited access button.
Fill in the root password.
Click Authenticate to confirm.

section.para: To turn off administrative mode, proceed as follows:

step.para: Click Administrative access.
To confirm, click Limit access.

abstract.para: Using the Cockpit Overview part, you can perform changes to the default server configuration or the configuration you provided during the manual installation. In this part, you can change the host name or change the system date or time zone.

section.title: Changing the server host name
section.para: To change the host name, proceed as follows:

step.para: Navigate to the Overview page.
In the Configuration part, click edit.
Fill in the following:

listitem.para: Pretty host name—a user-defined free-form host name
Real host name—the name of the device in the network

section.title: Changing the system time or time zone
section.para: To change the system time or time zone, proceed as follows:

procedure.title: Changing system time or time zone

step.para: Navigate to the Overview page.
Click the System time value.
In the pop-up window you can change the following:

listitem.para: Time zone—the value set during the manual installation or, in case of raw images, set to UTC.
Set time—by default, NTP is used for time synchronization. You can set the time manually or, if you defined alternative NTP servers, you can use those NTP servers for time synchronization.

section.para: You can filter the logs according to the following criteria:

listitem.para: Time. For details, refer to .
Priority. For details, refer to .
Identifier. You can filter logs for a particular service, daemon or process. Available identifiers are parsed from the logs currently displayed according to the set filters.
Free-form filters. For details, refer to .

note.title: The filter criteria are combined
note.para: When changing any of the time, priority or identifier criteria, the other ones are still applied. For example, if you change the time criterion to Last 24 hours, the priority and identifier criteria remain the same.

section.title: Filtering according to time
section.para: To filter the logs according to a specific time, you can choose from the following values:

listitem.para: Displays logs for the current boot only. The Resume button enables continuous refreshing of currently displayed logs.
Displays logs relevant to the previous boot.
Displays logs that were recorded within the last 24 hours.
Displays logs that were recorded within the last 7 days.

section.title: Filtering according to priority
section.para: The standard syslog severity levels are used (sorted from most to least severe):

listitem.para: The system is unusable. This is a panic condition.
This log requires your immediate action.
Failures in primary systems. You should correct the problem immediately.
Not an urgent error, but should be handled within a specific time.
Not an error, but indicates that an error might occur if no action is taken.
Unusual events that are not errors. No immediate actions are required.
Normal operational messages that serve as a confirmation that the system works properly.
These messages are used just to debug the system.

section.title: Logs filters
section.para: You can refine the logs view here according to the following criteria:

listitem.para: Logs for the specified date or newer will be displayed. You can specify the time in the following way:
using the absolute date in the format YYYY-MM-DD

using relative time by prefixing the value with - or + and specifying units. You can use the following units: seconds or s, minutes or min, hours or h, days or d, weeks or w, months or m, and years or y.
Logs for the specified date or older will be displayed. You can specify the time in the following way:
using the absolute date in the format YYYY-MM-DD

using relative time by prefixing the value with - or + and specifying units. You can use the following units: seconds or s, minutes or min, hours or h, days or d, weeks or w, months or m, and years or y.
Enter an integer: 0 means the current boot, -1 is for the previous boot, 1 for the first boot, 2 for the second, etc.
Specify a systemd unit for which you want to display logs. Use one of the formats:

Enter a string that you want to find in the log messages. You can also use PERL-compatible regular expressions. Alternatively, you can filter messages according to message log fields in the format FIELD=VALUE. For example, CODE_LINE=349 displays logs with this value.

section.para: The Storage page enables you to monitor traffic on your drives, repartition your system, manage NFS mount, view storage logs, and create RAIDs or LVM.
The graphs on the Storage page display reading and writing data flow to devices. Each device in the graph has a different color. Hover over the displayed data flow peak to identify the device name.
The Filesystems view enables you to create a partition table and to format or mount file systems. You can sort the mounted partition according to Name or Mount point.
To format the partition, proceed as follows:

step.para: Navigate to the Storage page.
In the Filesystem view, click the partition you want to format.
Click Format next to the particular partition description to open the format window.
Enter a unique name of the partition.
In Mount point, specify to which directory the partition will be mounted. The Mount point field is mandatory.
In Type, select the file system type. Btrfs is mandatory for the / partition.
If needed, configure the encryption:

listitem.para: Enter a passphrase to unlock the encrypted partition.
The passphrase is stored in /etc/luks-keys and you are not asked for the passphrase on next boot.
You can pass a list of options described in supported encrypted options.

step.para: Select the Mount options. In the Custom mount options text field, you can enter a comma-separated list of options. For common options, refer to File system Independent Mount Options. Those options are used in the options part of the /etc/fstab file.

note.title: The partition must be formatted
note.para: Before you try to mount a partition or disk, you need to format the device first. For details, refer to .

section.para: To mount a partition, proceed as follows:

step.para: Navigate to the Storage page.
In the Filesystems view, click the device to mount.
Click Mount to open the Mount filesystem window.
Specify the Mount point.

Select the mount options in the Custom mount options text field, you can enter a comma-separated list of options. For common options, refer to File system Independent Mount Options. Those options are used in the options part of the /etc/fstab file.
Select at which booting stage the partition must be mounted.
Click Mount to proceed.

abstract.para: The NFS mounts view under the Storage page enables you to add, edit or delete NFS mounts.

section.title: Adding an NFS mount point
section.para: To add an NFS mount point, proceed as follows:

step.para: Navigate to the Storage page.
From the three-line menu, select New NFS mounts view.
Specify the following values:

listitem.para: Provide the IP address or name of the NFS server.
Select the available path on the NFS server that can be mounted.
Specify a directory on the local system where the path will be mounted to.
Check any of the options:
Mount at boot – to mount the path automatically after each start or restart of the system.
Mount read only – you will not be able to perform changes to the data on the NFS path.
Custom mount options is a comma-separated list of the mount command options.

section.title: Editing existing NFS mount points
section.para: To edit an NFS mount, proceed as follows:

step.para: Navigate to the Storage page.
In the NFS mounts view, click on the particular NFS mount.
On the next screen, click Edit and specify the details described in .

abstract.para: Using Cockpit you can create or modify software RAIDS of different levels.

note.title: Sufficient number of disks
note.para: Make sure that you have enough disks available according to the RAID level.

section.para: To create a software RAID, proceed as follows:

step.para: Navigate to the Storage page.
Select the Create RAID device option in the three-line menu in the Devices view.
Enter the following parameters of the RAID:

listitem.para: Enter a unique name of the RAID.
Select one of the RAID levels.
The size of chunks in KBs. A chunk is the minimum amount of data read or written to each data disk in the array during a single read/write operation.
Select the disks that should be included in the RAID. The required number of disks depends on the selected RAID level.

step.para: Confirm the parameters by clicking Create. The RAID then appears in the Devices part.

abstract.para: Using the Storage plugin of Cockpit you can stop or delete a RAID. Here you can also remove or add disk to the array.

section.para: To modify an existing RAID, proceed as follows:

step.para: Navigate to the Storage page.
Click the RAID in Devices to open the RAID details view.
In the detailed view, you can stop or delete the RAID, add or remove disks and format the device.

With certain RAID levels, you can switch on the Bitmap option that enables you to synchronize only the changes after a disk is temporarily disconnected. If the Bitmap is off, all data on the disk will be synchronized.

note.title: Removing or adding disks
note.para: After any change to the disks number of the array, the system undergoes resynchronization that may take some time. Keep in mind that each RAID level requires a minimum number of disks, therefore, Cockpit does not allow removing the disks that are required by the particular RAID level.

section.para: To create a volume group of disks, proceed as follows:

step.para: Click Storage.
Under the three-line menu in Devices, select Create LVM2 volume group.
Enter the volume group name.
Select disks that will be part of the volume group.
Confirm the data with Create. The volume group appears in the Devices view.

section.para: If you have a volume group, you can create a logical block volume from it. To do so, proceed as follows:

step.para: Navigate to the Storage page.
In the Devices, click the volume group you want to use.
Click Create new logical volume
Specify a logical volume name. Select a block device and choose the size to use.
Select the Block device for filesystems.
Select the size to use.
Click Create to confirm the details.
Format the block volume by clicking Format and filling the details as described in .

section.para: If you have a volume group, you can create a thin logical volume as described below:

step.para: Navigate to the Storage page.
Click the volume group in Devices.
In the volume group details, click Create new logical volume.
Specify a logical volume name.
Select a pool of thinly provisioned volumes.
Select the size to use.
Click Create to confirm the details.
Create a thin volume by clicking Create thin volume.
Enter a unique name.
Select the size of the volume.
Click Create to confirm the thin volume.
You can create several volumes of the particular volume group by clicking Create thin volume again and repeating the steps above.
Format the volumes by clicking Format and filling the details as described in .

section.para: To perform any administration task on an existing logical volume, perform the following steps:

step.para: Navigate to the Storage page.
In the Filesystems view, click the logical volume.
Here you can perform the following actions with existing logical volumes:

listitem.para: In the three-dot menu, select Deactivate or Activate.
By clicking Mount and filling in the mount point and options, the volume will be mounted.
The shrink/grow function is not available for all file systems.
In the expanded details about the volume, click Shrink or Grow.
In the three-dot menu, select Delete.

section.para: After clicking Networking, you can view traffic on your system, manage firewall, manage network interfaces, or view network logs.

abstract.para: Cockpit enables you to create new zones or update the existing ones. In the firewall settings, you can add services to a zone or allow access to ports.

note.title: Cockpit service is mandatory
note.para: Do not remove the Cockpit service from the default firewall zone as the Cockpit service may get blocked, and you may get disconnected from the server.

section.title: Adding firewall zones
section.para: The public zone is the default firewall zone. To add a new zone, proceed as follows:

step.para: Navigate to the Networking page.
Click Edit rules and zones.
Click Add zone.
Select Trust level. Each trust level of network connections has a predefined set of included services (the Cockpit service is included in all trust levels).
Define allowed addresses within the zone. Select one of the values:

listitem.para: Entire subnet to allow all addresses in the subnet.
Range—a comma-separated list of IP addresses with the routing prefix, for example, 192.0.2.0/24, 2001:db8::/32.

step.para: Proceed with Add zone.

section.title: Adding allowed services and ports to a zone
section.para: You can add services to an existing firewall zone as described below:

procedure.title: Adding services to a firewall zone

step.para: Navigate to the Networking page.
Click Edit rules and zones.
Click Add services.
To add a service, check Services and select the services from the list.
To allow custom ports, check Custom ports and specify the port value for UDP and/or TCP. You can assign an identifier to this port.
To confirm the changes, click Add services or Add ports, respectively.

section.para: A bond interface is a combination of several network interfaces into one bond. Depending on the Mode (described further), network bonding can improve performance by increasing the network throughput and bandwidth. Network bonding can also increase fault tolerance by keeping overall connectivity even if some of the bonded interfaces stopped working.

section.title: Adding bonds

warning.title: Using DHCP when creating bonds may cause disconnection from Cockpit
warning.para: When you try to create a network bond, you will be disconnected from Cockpit as its IP address changes if the following conditions are met:

listitem.para: DHCP is used on the server running Cockpit
the currently used network interface is added to the new network bond

section.para: To add a bond, proceed as follows:

step.para: Navigate to the Networking page.
Click Add bond.
Specify the following parameters of the bond interface:

listitem.para: Enter a unique name of the interface.
Select which network interfaces should be grouped in the bond.
You can either select a specific MAC address of the underlying interface, or you can use any of the following options:
Use the permanent hardware address if the device has a MAC address.
During the bond activation, the MAC address is not changed.
A random MAC address is created on each connection attempt.
Creates a hashed MAC address.
Keep the default mode or select any of the following modes:
Transfers packets from the first available interface to the last. The mode offers fault tolerance and load balancing.
Only one interface in the bonding is active. If the active interface fails, the backup will be activated.
Balancing using a transmit hash policy. The default is a modulo device count. To select a different policy, specify the xmit_hash_policy option in the Option field.
Everything is transmitted on all interfaces.
A channel bonding that does not require any special switch support. The outgoing traffic is distributed according to the current load on each interface.
Includes adaptive transmit load balancing and receive load balancing, no special switch support is required.
This selection is available only for the Active Backup mode. You can select a particular interface that will be used as primary, while other interfaces in the bond are used as secondary.
Select the type of link monitoring.
Specifies the intervals at which the particular link monitor performs checks. The value is in ms.

Define the time in ms for how long the bond is disabled after a link has been activated. The value should be a multiple of the Monitoring interval value, otherwise it will be rounded to the nearest value. Available only for the MII link monitor.

Define the time in ms for how long the bond is disabled if a link failure has been detected. The value should be a multiple of the Monitoring interval value, otherwise it will be rounded to the nearest value. Available only for the MII link monitor.
Specify the list of host IP addresses that you want to monitor. Available only for the ARP link monitor.

step.para: Proceed with Apply.

section.title: Modifying bonds
section.para: To modify a bond, proceed as follows:

step.para: Navigate to the Networking page.
Click on the particular bond name to open the details.
You can modify the following bond parameters:

listitem.para: Select a MAC address from the list.
The bond connects automatically by default. Uncheck the box to disable the automatic connection.
After clicking edit, you can set an IP address and configure a specific DNS, DNS search domain and Routes.
After clicking edit, you can specify a particular value of the maximum transmission unit in bytes.
After clicking edit, you can edit the same parameters as when you were creating the bond interface.

abstract.para: A network bridge is a device that creates a single aggregated network from multiple networks.

section.title: Creating network bridges

warning.title: Using DHCP when creating network bridges may cause disconnection from Cockpit
warning.para: When you try to create a network bridge, you will be disconnected from Cockpit as its IP address changes if the following conditions are met:

listitem.para: DHCP is used on the server running Cockpit
the currently used network interface is added to the new network bridge

section.para: To create a network bridge, proceed as follows:

step.para: Navigate to the Networking page.
In the Interfaces view, click Add bridge.
Specify the following:

listitem.para: Specify a unique name of the bridge.
Select interfaces to be included in the bridge.

STP is a network protocol used for Ethernet networks that prevents bridge loops by setting a preferred link whenever network switches are connected with several links. This preferred link is used for all Ethernet traffic unless it fails. In that case, a redundant link is used instead. For details regarding STP, see STP.
If you enable the STP protocol, you can edit the following settings:
The lower the priority, the higher the probability of the switch to become the root switch.
Specify the time spent in the listening and learning state (in seconds). The default value is 15 s, but you can use any value between 4 and 30 s.
Specify the time between each bridge protocol data unit (BDPU) that is sent on a port (in seconds). The default value is 2 s, but the recommended range is 1 to 10 s.
Specify the maximum length of time that passes before a bridge port saves its configuration BPDU information.

section.title: Modifying or deleting existing bridges
section.para: To modify or delete a bridge, proceed as follows:

step.para: Navigate to the Networking page.
In the Interfaces view, click the bridge name to open the details.
There you can delete the bridge by clicking Delete, or modify it by changing any of the following details:

listitem.para: The bridge connects automatically by default. To disable the automatic connection, uncheck the option.
After clicking edit, you can set the IP address and configure a specific DNS, DNS search domain and Routes.
By clicking edit, you can edit all parameters of the bridge.

abstract.para: A virtual local area network is a logical subnetwork that groups devices from different physical LANs.

section.title: Creating virtual local area network
section.para: To add a VLAN, proceed as follows:

step.para: Navigate to the Networking page.
In the Interfaces view, click Add VLAN.
Fill in the VLAN details:

listitem.para: Select the parent network interface.
Specify an ID in the range 1–4094.
Enter the name of the VLAN.

section.title: Modifying or deleting existing VLANs
section.para: To modify or delete an existing VLAN, proceed as follows:

step.para: Navigate to the Networking page.
In the Interface view, click the VLAN name.
Either delete the VLAN by clicking Delete, or change any of the VLAN details:

listitem.para: Select the parent network interface.
Specify an ID in the range 1–4094.
Enter the name of the VLAN.

section.para: After the first login to Cockpit, you need to start Podman. Keep the default check box selected to start Podman automatically on each boot.
The Podman containers page enables you to pull images from registries and manage your container. You can also filter the view by entering a filter criterion into the filter field.

note.title: openSUSE registry and Docker Hub not enabled by default
note.para: The openSUSE registry and Docker Hub are not configured in the default installation. To download container images from those registries, you need to add the registries to the /etc/containers/registries.conf file as follows:

section.para: In the Images view, you can download, update or delete already pulled images. Each function is available under the three-dot menu. After clicking the menu, there are the following options:

listitem.para: Download new image: How to proceed with downloading an image is described in .
Pull all images: Cockpit pulls new versions of the container images you already downloaded.
Prune all unused images: All images that are not used by any container will be removed.

step.para: In the Podman containersImages view, open the three-dot menu and select Download new image.

Select the Owner to define who can see the downloaded image. The System restricts the image visibility to users with administrative access. The image downloaded under the User owner is visible to the regular user and also to all other users with the administrative access.
Choose a preferred image registry or proceed with All registries.
Define the Tag. The default value is latest.
Fill in the image name or description in the Search for field to start the search.
Cockpit suggests possible images according to the entered name, registry and tag.
Select the desired image and click Download.

section.title: Running new containers from images

note.title: Image required to run a container
note.para: To run a container, you need a container image. The image can be pulled using Podman or Cockpit. When using Cockpit, you can pull an image in advance as described in , or you can pull the image directly from the Create container form as described below. .

section.para: To run a new container, proceed as follows:

step.para: Navigate to the Podman containers page.
If you pulled an image in advance:
In the Images view, click Show images.
Click Create container next to the image you want to use.
If you do not have the image, click Create container in the Containers view.
In the Create container window, enter the container details as described below. Note that some options are available only for system administrators.
In the Details tab, enter the following details:

listitem.para: Select whether the container will be visible only for users with sudo privileges by selecting system. The user defines that the container is visible to privileged users and regular users.
Specify a unique name for the container.
This field is enabled if you do not have the image. After you start typing the image name, Cockpit makes suggestions of images in the configured registries.
The checkbox is available if you are creating the container from an already downloaded image. If selected, the latest image version is pulled before the container is started.
You can specify a command to run in the container.
Select the option to have access to the container using a terminal. If not selected, the container will be in the detached state.
You can limit maximum memory consumption of the container by checking the box and specifying the limit.

Specify the weight of the container to use CPU time. The default weight is 1024. The weight applies only if containers are under high load. If the tasks in one container are idle, other containers may use its CPU time.

If you have four containers, two of them have CPU shares of 512 and the other two have 1024. Thus, under high load, the containers with lower CPU shares get only 16,5% of CPU time, while those with 1024 CPU shares get 33% of CPU time.

step.para: In the Integration tab, you can enter the following parameters:

listitem.para: After you click the Add port mapping button, specify the host IP address, the host port to map the container port onto, the container port and select the protocol. If you do not set the host IP address or set the value to 0.0.0.0, the port is bound to ALL host IP addresses. If you omit the host port, a random one is used for the mapping.
This field maps a path in a container onto a path on the host machine. Fill in the host path, the container path and select the SELinux label.
The SELinux label private defines that the volume is accessible only from the particular container. The shared label means that all containers can access the volume.
To define environment variables in the container, click Add variable and fill in Key and Value. You can enter multiple variables by adding more lines.

step.para: In the Health check tab, you can set a time period of commands triggering to check the status of the container. Fill in the following parameters:

listitem.para: Specify the command that is triggered to check the container status.
Specify the interval of checks in seconds.
The maximum time in seconds to wait before the interval is considered failed.
The time interval after the container is started when the health check is not performed.
Specify how many times the check can be performed before the status is considered as unhealthy.
Select the action to take after a container is considered unhealthy.

step.para: To create the container, click Create or Create and run to create and start the container.

section.title: Further actions with running containers
section.para: Under the three-dot menu, you can perform the following actions:

listitem.para: delete the container
pause the container
commit changes performed to the container, for example, installing packages to the container
checkpoint the container—write the state of the container to disk and stop the container
restart the container, either by regular Restart, where processes running inside the container are stopped, or by Force restart, where the processes are killed, and you may lose data

stop the container, either by regular Stop, Force stop or Checkpoint. When using Checkpoint, the state of all processes in the container is written to the disk, and after the next start, the container is restored to the same point before stopping.

section.para: By expanding the container details, you can access the container's terminal in the Console tab and view its information in other tabs.
Cockpit enables you to create pods in which you can then create containers. To create a pod, follow the steps:

step.para: Navigate to the Podman containers page.
Click Create pod.
Fill in the pod details:

listitem.para: Enter a unique name of the pod.
Specify whether the pod will be visible only under root privileges or also to regular users.

After clicking Add port mapping, you can map a pod port onto a host port. Specify the containers port, assign the desired host port and IP address. If the host IP address is not set or set to 0.0.0.0, the port is bonded to all host IP addresses. If you omit the host port number, a random port number is assigned to the mapping.
After clicking Add volume, you can map a directory on the host onto a container's volume. Select the host path, enter the path in containers and select the SELinux labeling.

step.para: Click Create to confirm the pod creation.

important.title: Existing containers cannot be added to pods
important.para: During the planning, note that only new containers can be run in a pod. You cannot add an already created container that has not been run under a pod to any pod.

section.para: To create containers in a pod, follow the steps:

step.para: Navigate to the Podman containers page.
In the desired pod group, click Create container in pod.
Fill in the container details as described in . Remember that the owner of new containers is the same as the owner of the particular pod.

abstract.para: The Cockpit Accounts screen enables you to administer user accounts and groups.

note.title: User administration only for server administrators
note.para: Only users with Administrative access can edit other users.

section.para: Using the Accounts Cockpit screen, you can perform the following tasks:

listitem.para: Creating new users of the system as described in
Assigning sudo privileges to user accounts as described in
Forcing a change of a user's password as described in
Locking a particular user account as described in

section.para: To modify a user account, proceed as follows:

step.para: Navigate to the Accounts page.
Click the account you want to modify.
In the user details view, you can perform the following actions:

listitem.para: Click Delete to remove the user from the system.
By clicking Terminate session, you can log a particular user out of the system.
You can set a date when the account will expire. The default is to never expire.
You can disallow the user to use their password to log in. The user then must use a different method of authentication.
Click Set password to set a new password for the account.
By clicking Force change, the user will have to change the password on the next login.
Click edit to set whether or when the password expires.
You can add an SSH key for passwordless authentication via SSH. Click Add key, paste the contents of the public SSH key and confirm it by clicking Add.

section.para: To add a new user to the system, proceed as follows:

step.para: Navigate to the Accounts page.
Click Create new account to open the window that enables you to add a new user.

Fill in the user account details. You can assign a different home directory to the user in the drop-down Home directory menu. If you do not specify a directory, the standard /home/USERNAME path is used.
If you select Disallow password authentication, the user will have to use an authentication method other than filling in password, for example, SSH login.
Click Create to confirm the account.
To add an SSH key to the account, you need to modify the account as described in .

abstract.para: The topic covers the creation of user groups.

section.para: To create a user group, proceed as follows:

step.para: Navigate to the Accounts page.
Click Create new group.
Enter a unique name of the group and specify or leave the default one.

note.para: The already existing group ID cannot be overwritten. Group IDs under 1000 are usually reserved for system accounts, services, and so on. If you create a group with an ID less than 1000, the group cannot be later deleted using Cockpit.

section.para: The following sections describe how to start, stop and restart a service, target, socket, timer or path.
To manage a systemd unit, proceed as follows:

step.para: Click the Services page.
Select the appropriate tab (System services, Targets, Sockets, Timers or Paths).
Click the unit you want to administer.
In the unit details, you can view relations to other systemd units, the status of the unit, or you can perform the following actions that can be found in the three-dot menu:

listitem.para: Start if the unit is not running
Restart the running unit
Stop the running unit

Disallow running—that will stop the service permanently, including all its dependencies. Keep in mind that the dependent service can be used by other units, and disallowing the unit may cause serious troubles for the system.

abstract.para: systemd timers help you to automate recurring tasks. A systemd timer can control triggering of systemd services and handling of events.

note.title: Overriding existing timers
note.para: The default set of systemd timers is stored in /usr/lib/systemd. If you create a timer with already existing names, the default unit file is not overwritten, but a new one is created in /etc/systemd/system/ that overrides the default unit file. To restore the timer to the default one, delete the timer unit file in /etc/systemd/system/.
If you try to create a timer that already exists in the /etc/systemd/system/ directory, the unit file will be overwritten, and the previous changes are lost.

section.para: To create a systemd timer using Cockpit, proceed as follows:

step.para: Navigate to Services.
In the Timers tab, click Create timer.
Fill in the details:

listitem.para: The name of the timer that will be used in the unit name and in the service unit name as well. For example, specifying the name example will create the following unit files: /etc/systemd/system/example.timer and /etc/systemd/system/example.service.
You can provide a short description of the timer.
The command to be invoked when the timer is triggered.

The timer can be triggered each time you reboot your machine or at a specific time. For the After system boot option, you can define the delay of the service invocation. For the At specific time option, specify when the service should be invoked.

abstract.para: The SELinux tool enables you to switch between SELinux modes and view current modifications of the SELinux policy.

important.title: Missing SELinux module
important.para: The SELinux Cockpit module is visible only if SELinux is enabled on the system. If you cannot access the module, SELinux is probably disabled. To check that SELinux is enabled, run:

section.para: On SUSE Linux Enterprise Server, SELinux is in the enforcing mode by default. To temporarily switch to the permissive mode, click the button with the Enforcing label. Note that the change persists only until the next boot. If you need to perform a persistent change of the mode, edit the configuration file /etc/selinux/config.

The System modifications lists all modifications performed on the default SELinux policy. If you want to export the modifications and reuse them on different servers, click View automation script. In the new window, you can copy a shell script or the Ansible configuration file that can be applied on other servers.
In the SELinux page, you can view access denial messages from the audit log. On top of that, Cockpit provides possible ways of solving the access denial. To do so, follow the steps:

step.para: Navigate to the SELinux page.
In SELinux access control errors, expand the details regarding access denial.
To view the audit log record, click Audit log.
To view possible solutions, click Solutions. Some solutions may be applied directly through Cockpit by clicking Apply this solution.
